Variable Age: contains 4 categories
End up with numerical codes in the "ds_fin" data frame - useful for later correlation plots
```{r}
#Age
ggplot(ds, aes(x=reorder(Age, Age, function(x)-length(x)))) + 
  geom_bar(fill='red') +  labs(x='Age')

# Transform into numerical codes for the levels
ds$Age <- as.factor(ds$Age)
f <- factor(ds$Age, levels =  c('less than 40','40-49','50-59','60 or older'))
n <- as.numeric(f)
nn <- n - 1
ds_fin$Age <- nn
table(ds_fin$Age)
```

Variable Gender
```{r}
#Gender: Male=1, Female=0
ggplot(ds, aes(x=reorder(Gender, Gender, function(x)-length(x)))) + 
  geom_bar(fill='green') +  labs(x='Gender')
ds_fin <- ds
ds_fin$Gender <- ifelse(ds$Gender == 'Male', 1, 0)
table(ds_fin$Gender)
```
Family Diabetes: cast into binary variable. 
```{r}
ds_fin$Family_Diabetes <- ifelse(ds$Family_Diabetes == 'yes', 1, 0)
ggplot(ds, aes(x=reorder(Family_Diabetes, Family_Diabetes, function(x)-length(x)))) + 
  geom_bar(fill='green') +  labs(x='Family Diabetes')
table(ds_fin$Family_Diabetes) # very equal distribution
```

The following variables are mostly ordinally scaled, meaning that they have levels, but they are not equally spaced. In theory, taking them as numerical values between 0-3 is not a good idea. We can see if we can make them as dummies. 
Blood Pressure level: contains same values typed differently.
Fix different values for the blood pressure level variable to have them
equal

```{r}
ds$BPLevel[ds$BPLevel == 'High'] <- 'high'
ds$BPLevel[ds$BPLevel == 'Low'] <- 'low'
ds$BPLevel[ds$BPLevel == 'normal '] <- 'normal'
ds$BPLevel <- as.factor(ds$BPLevel)
# check if problem is fixed
unique(ds['BPLevel'])

# take a look at the distribution of BPLevel
ggplot(ds, aes(x=reorder(BPLevel, BPLevel, function(x)-length(x)))) + 
  geom_bar(fill='blue') +  labs(x='Blood Pressure Level')

f <- factor(ds$BPLevel, levels =  c('low','normal','high'))
n <- as.numeric(f)
nn <- n - 1
ds_fin$BPLevel <- nn
table(ds_fin$BPLevel)
```
Next, consider the variable highBP, which we will later analyze for correlation with BPLevel, 
since they potentially carry very similar information.
```{r}
#HighBP: Yes=1, No=0
ggplot(ds, aes(x=reorder(highBP, highBP, function(x)-length(x)))) + 
  geom_bar(fill='blue') +  labs(x='High Blood Pressure')
ds$highBP <- as.factor(ds$highBP)
ds_fin$highBP <- ifelse(ds$highBP == 'yes', 1, 0)
```

## 3.1. Descriptive statistics

```{r}
# check correlation between variables
df_cor <- ds_fin %>% mutate_if(is.character, as.factor)
```

# 4. Model data

Use regression and predictions for forecasting future values Or use
classification to identify groups

Reduce dimensionality of the data set - not all our values are
essentials to predicting the model

Select relevant features that contribute to the prediction of results or
apply shrinkage regressions

```{r}
log_reg <- glm(Diabetic ~., data = ds_fin, family = binomial)
summary(log_reg)
```

Diagnostics
```{r}
log_prob <- predict(log_reg, type = 'response')
logistic_pred <- rep(0, 905)
logistic_pred[log_prob>0.5] <- 1

test <- ds_fin$Diabetic[ds_fin]

# since the method that predicts from the model has erased 47 NA observations,
# we need to take only the complete observations from the Diabetic column
# in order to compute the confusion matrix
na_removed <- na.omit(ds_fin)
table(logistic_pred, na_removed$Diabetic)
```


Deviance - not very informative
```{r}
dev_test <- log_reg$null.deviance - log_reg$deviance
df <- log_reg$df.null - log_reg$df.residual
p.val <- 1-pchisq(dev_test, df)
p.val
```
```{r}
log_reg_resid <- residuals(log_reg, type = 'deviance')
plot(log_reg_resid~fitted(log_reg))
qqnorm(log_reg_resid)
qqline(log_reg_resid)
```

# 5. Interpret data

How do we present our analysis: basically answer the questions we set in
the beginning using our results - technical details are necessary but
make them accessible - tell a story


Compare probability between age groups for diabetes
```{r}
aov_age <- aov(ds_fin$Diabetic~ds_fin$Age)
tukey_age <- TukeyHSD(aov_age)
plot(tukey_age)
```
